{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3417823,"name":"Marshall Tappen","username":"MTappen","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/aca169/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-24T18:39:53.503Z","cooked":"

What have people found to be the best practices for mixing Choreo with closed-loop visual driving?

Last season, we had good success driving to pick up notes using a Limelight/Google Coral combo (thanks to the community for some great open-source models!)

Stitching the closed-loop segments with PathPlanner path follower went ok, but not great. We would guess where the robot would end up during the pick-up stage, then hoped the PID controllers in the path follower would get the robot back on track. In the end, I felt like the there was a lot of variation in the final pose of the robot after we ran a PathPlanner path that followed a visual servoing segment.

Did anyone have a flow that worked well? Is there a good way to get the robot “back on track” to a PathPlanner path after a dynamic routine?

Thanks!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-08-24T18:39:53.503Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":85,"reads":134,"readers_count":133,"score":451.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470216,"topic_slug":"getting-back-onto-a-choreo-pathplanner-path-after-driving-with-vision","display_username":"Marshall Tappen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55817,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/getting-back-onto-a-choreo-pathplanner-path-after-driving-with-vision/470216/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3417824,"name":"Ashton A","username":"UHDbits","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/u/a5b964/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-24T18:52:17.738Z","cooked":"

We did this just with PathPlanner (without Choreo paths) during the season, and had zero issues with it figuring out
where it needed to go.

I would make sure you have both initial path replanning and dynamic path replanning enabled in your ReplanningConfig when you configure your AutoBuilder. I am not sure if this is possible when using Choreo, because as far as I know, Choreo paths do not support path replanning.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-08-24T18:52:24.141Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":119,"readers_count":118,"score":53.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470216,"topic_slug":"getting-back-onto-a-choreo-pathplanner-path-after-driving-with-vision","display_username":"Ashton A","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63823,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1165 - Lead Programmer/Driver"},"post_url":"/t/getting-back-onto-a-choreo-pathplanner-path-after-driving-with-vision/470216/2","custom_user_title":"1165 - Lead Programmer/Driver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3417835,"name":"Amicus1","username":"Amicus1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/a9adbd/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-24T19:59:36.863Z","cooked":"

This is definitely a weak spot with Choreo. As a general idea, you would want to make the robot match a particular state in the trajectory, then play the trajectory from that state. The issue with just running the trajectory and letting the PIDs catch up is that the trajectory command finishes at a particular time, whether or not the robot caught up. I don’t know what kind of algorithm would be good for pathing to a particular intermediate state of the trajectory, especially one that has non-zero velocity.

Thanks. I think we had that turned off because we weren’t sure how it would behave. We will try turning it back on.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-08-24T20:39:10.384Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":94,"readers_count":93,"score":18.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470216,"topic_slug":"getting-back-onto-a-choreo-pathplanner-path-after-driving-with-vision","display_username":"Marshall Tappen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":63823,"username":"UHDbits","name":"Ashton A","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/u/a5b964/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55817,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/getting-back-onto-a-choreo-pathplanner-path-after-driving-with-vision/470216/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3417848,"name":"Marshall Tappen","username":"MTappen","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/aca169/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-24T21:04:41.730Z","cooked":"

I don’t have a good feel for what is possible on the RoboRIO, but I could imagine quadratic system that optimized for position, with cost terms to make position, velocity, and acceleration match the trajectory as close as possible. You could add a few additional padding time steps to allow it to catch up. It results in a banded matrix, there is a dynamic programming solution for solving it. If you need non-quadratic, it could be something like an iLQR solver.

Limited by compute, you could run the optimization over a set of different numbers of padding timesteps and choose the one that had some combination of lowest loss and smallest amount of pad.

Hopefully the new control system will have much more horsepower in the main chip and open up more dynamic possibilities.

I would make sure you have both initial path replanning and dynamic path replanning enabled in your ReplanningConfig when you configure your AutoBuilder.
